The analysis of the experimental data [ 17, 48, 57, 58, 59, 60] on the ordered phases of various BTA–cored three-armed stars reveals that the intermolecular separations in the stacks range from 3.51 to 3.89
A ˚
for the molecules with different periphery around the star center. Apparently, there is no clear relationship between the distance d and the bulkiness of the star arms. For example, for almost the same azobenzene [ 17] and alkoxy azobenzene [ 48] BTA–stars, the values differ by 0.47
A ˚
, whereas the
π

π
stacking separations are nearly equal to 3.6
A ˚
for shorter (2-methoxyethyl [ 57] and carboxymethyl [ 60]) and longer/bulkier arms (linear and branched C 8–C 11 alkyls [ 58], Glu-based oligopeptides [ 59]). The reason may lie in the many possibilities the molecules can be assembled in the ordered phases: The stars can build segregated columns, be rotated around the core in the star plane or shifted laterally along the columns.
